Directors have been informed by the President in the beginning I of May of this year of the possibility of two loans, one to the Belgian Congo and one to the Kingdom of Belgium. KAMARCK: Mr. Chairman and gentlemen, economic
development in the Congo is a very recent tnng. It began scarcely fifty years ago and has encountered very great obstacles because of the nature of the problem. The country 1s very large, about as large as the United States east of the MissisSippi, with all the main productive regions about
a thous and miles inland from any sea. It 1s very sparsely  4
populated. There a.re oIlly about eleven million Africans and less than sixty thousand Europeans. The populatIon itself was and largely is stIll very primitive. It 1s a people that, before the Europeans came, didn't have the plow or the wheel, didn't know the art of writing, and still does not have a d raft animal.
Still, in spite of all of this, considerable progress has been made in the last fifty years. The Congo has become an important source of' primary agricultural and mineral raw materials. Last year exports reached a total of $330,000,000 equivalent. ThIs development, however, has run up against several over-all problems and several over-all limitations. The main ones of these are shortages in transport and electric pover, and a lack of qualified native labor. Also, the native agriculture has developed about as far as it can develop without a change, a fundamental change, in the whole baSis. The Belgians, therefore, have prepared a ten-year plan for the economic and social development of the Congo which entered into execution in 1950. This plan provides for public investment tn basic equipment and the necessary social services to go with it. The original estimate of the cost was that it would be around the equivalent of $520 million. Based on the experience of' the first two years, a reappraisal of the plan
Is goIng to be made next year in the light of experience as  5 to whether there needs to be a change in the plan, and also in the light of the change in prices. It is nov expected that it will cost in the neighborhood of $660 million equivalent. It is also expected there will be roughly an equivalent amount of private investment in the productive sectors, that is, in
industry, in mining, and in agriculture. The original estimates provided for about 50 percent of
the total cost of the plan to go into transport -- water, road, and air. A further 10 percent was to go into communicaÂ­ tions, water supply, electriCity, and the remaining 40 percent
into these necessary basic social services. On the whole, the plan appears to be very well worked
out and well designed to meet the needs of the Congo. There is to be a further increase in the production of the commodities in which the Congo specializes, and further development of industry. Also, the 40 percent of the plan which is going into the social services is Vitally necessary. This 40 percent is going into native education, housing, public health, and in the economic and social development of the native communities. It is impossible for the Congo to progress unless the native population is brought along
in the advance of civilization. There has been very small European immigration into the Congo. As I said, the total has reached less than sixty
thousand. Because or the climate and because or policy,  6
there are no plans for further large immigration, so that
the development of the Congo depends upon how rapidly the
native himself can progress in learning the necessary technic I
skills.
The consensus of opinion in the Congo, both among the
public and among those Belgians that best know the Congo,
that is, the businessmen and economic experts, is that the
plan is very well worked out. There is really remarkable unanimity on that score.
As I mentioned, the plan is based on the assumption that
as the public investment creates the possibilities, private
investment will come in to take advantage of those possiÂ­
bilities. That assumption seems to be very well founded.
From experience in the first year and a half of the plan,
and from the investment programs of the private enterprises
already existing in the Congo and in the interest shown by
investors abroad in the Congo, there seems to be very little
doubt but that as the basic equipment, the transport, expands
the private investment will come in to take advantage of
these opportunities.
In the first year and a half of the plan, from
January 1, 1950, to last July 1st, a total of only around $60 million was spent on the plan. This was largely due to
the usual inherent difficulties in starting a program as
large as this one, that is, preparing a detailed plan, asking  7 for bids, the contractor getting started, and so on. However,! that initial period is substantially over, and in the next two years, that is, from July 1st to June 30, 1953, the Belgians estimate, and it appears reasonable, that they will be able to spend in the neighborhood of $220 million, and that is the program which the Bank is helping to finance. On the whole, the administration of the plan and the private investment in the Congo is in very competent hands. The people appear to be capable, energetic, hard working, and really devoted to the cause of the Congo. If the plan is successful, exports should rise by from one - third to
one - half, and the national income of the Congo should increase by 50 to 100 percent.
Taking into consideration all of the factors which I have just mentioned, and the fact that the plan is well worked out and is in capable hands, I would say that the chances of success of the plan are excellent.
